title: ASX flat amid global uncertainty
text:
"It's very hard to determine typically how these events will play out and deeply hard to determine what the impact of these events will be," said Avenir Capital chief investment officer Adrian Warner.

The major banks were largely mixed on Wednesday, highlighting the uncertainty in the local market.

Westpac slid 0.2 per cent to $28.91 after it announced late in the session that its cash earnings in the second half of 2019 would be cut by around $341 million due to its customer remediation programs.

NAB dropped 0.5 per cent to $28.87 while ANZ rose 0.2 per cent to $27.89 and Commonwealth Bank climbed 0.4 per cent to $79.94.

The healthcare sector was hit hard, with a number of stocks falling heavily. Pro Medicus lost 6.1 per cent to $28.19, Mayne Pharma fell 4.4 per cent to 55¢ and ResMed closed the session 2.7 per cent lower at $18.50.

Mining stocks hit

Lithium stocks dropped across the board on Wednesday after Rio Tinto announced it had found high grades of lithium in rock and tailings waste at its borates business in California's Death Valley.

Advertisement

Rio's energy and minerals chief executive Bold Baatar said it had the potential to become America’s largest domestic producer of battery-grade lithium.

Galaxy Resources plummeted 7.1 per cent to 85¢ and Pilbara Minerals wiped 3.4 per cent to 28.5¢.

Service Stream shares traded weaker, dropping 4.3 per cent to $2.65, after managing director Leigh Mackender sold down half his holding in the company, selling 1 million shares for $2.7 million. It was the second time this year Mr Mackender had sold more than 1 million shares.

WiseTech Global returned from a trading halt, soaring 8.5 per cent to $28.53 after denying the claims of a second scathing report from US hedge fund J Capital Research.

The report had claimed WiseTech made a series of disastrous acquisitions in order to maintain a facade of being a high growth company.

Iron ore stocks traded higher on Wednesday on the back of firmer prices after Brazilian miner Vale reduced its iron ore sales guidance for 2019.

"The sales downgrade comes after Vale temporarily suspended the disposal of tailings at the Itabiruçu dam," said CBA mining & energy commodities analyst Vivek Dhar.

Advertisement

"While the amendment only implies a reduction of six million tonnes per annum of iron ore, the decrease is concentrated in two to three months."

Rio Tinto rose 0.4 per cent to $89.80 and Fortescue Metals Group added 2.2 per cent to close at $8.71.

Western Areas extended its solid performance this year, firming 4.2 per cent to $3.25 on Wednesday after it reported solid production and cash flow in the September quarter.

Gold stocks also traded higher, as risk averse investors sought safer havens amid heightened uncertainty over Brexit and US corporate earnings.

Gold Road Resources in particular soared after reporting on Tuesday the ramp-up of its Gruyere mine was "progressing well" and reaffirming its production guidance at the upper end of its 75,000 ounce to 100,000 ounce target. Its shares rose 13.7 per cent to $1.17.

Saracen Mineral Holdings advanced 5.1 per cent to $3.71 and Resolute Mining climbed 0.8 per cent to $1.20.
description: A mixed session of US corporate earnings weighed stocks on Wall Street, with investors uncertain on how companies were fairing in the slowing economy.
